Promotion of diphosphine ligands (PPh2(CH2) n PPh2, n = 1, 2, 3, 5, 6) for supported Rh/SiO2 catalysts in heterogeneous ethene hydroformylation Ning Huang Boyang Liu Xiaocheng Lan Binhang Yan Tiefeng Wang ⁎ Beijing Key Laboratory of Green Reaction Engineering and Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Green Reaction Engineering and Technology Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Green Reaction Engineering and Technology, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Hydroformylation is applied in industry to convert olefin and syngas to value-added products. Rh promoted by phosphine ligands are highly efficient catalysts for this reaction. The promotion mechanism of phosphines has been well studied in homogeneous system. It is important to extend the use of these ligands to heterogeneous system. The dpp* (PPh2(CH2) n PPh2, n = 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6) ligands were introduced to Rh/SiO2 and the ethene gaseous hydroformylation reaction was tested. Compared to unmodified Rh/SiO2, all the catalysts modified by phosphine showed enhanced activity (~100 times higher for the best ligand) and oxygenate selectivity (from 65% to ~97%). Among the investigation, L5 and L6 ligands exhibited the best performance while L1 and L2 only gave slight promotion. CO cutoff transient experiments were designed to identify the rate-limiting step (RLS) of hydroformylation reaction over the present catalysts. A mechanism was proposed for the change of RLS over the phosphine modified catalysts. Combined with in situ FTIR results, the relationship between electronic state and catalytic activity of the catalyst was verified. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous hydroformylation ethene phosphine ligands rate-limiting step carbon monoxide 1 Introduction Hydroformylation reaction is one of the most widely used processes in industry, [1-3] which converts olefin and syngas (CO and H2) to aldehydes with 100% atom economy. More than 10 million tons of oxygenates are produced from hydroformylation each year [2,4]. These oxygenates as well as their ramifications such as alcohols, carboxylic acids, esters and amines are value-added chemicals. The traditional catalysts for hydroformylation was Co homogeneous species [5,6]. Under syngas atmosphere, carbonyl cobalt was formed and accelerated the reaction. However, Co catalysts need high temperature and pressure and have relatively low selectivity to aldehydes. In 1970s, the Rh-phosphine coordination compound, famous as Wilkinson's catalyst, was developed for hydroformylation reactions [7]. This kind of catalysts are active at mild conditions and have high hydroformylation selectivity. Phosphine modified homogeneous catalysts have been intensively studied. Various phosphine ligands, such as monophosphines, bulky monophosphate [8], N-pyrrolylphosphines [9], and several different bidentate [10] and multidentate ligands [11], have been designed for hydroformylation reactions to enhance activity and selectivity. The influence of phosphine has also been studied [12]. It is typically considered that the electronic-withdraw ligands are favorable for hydroformylation reactions [1,8]. However, some researches reported that electronic-donor ligands, such as N-Pyrrolylphosphines type ligands, were more active in 1-butene hydroformylation [9]. Although the homogeneous catalysts have the advantages of high activities and selectivity, they suffers from difficulty of product separation and loss of expensive catalyst [13]. Immobilization of homogeneous catalyst on solid supports is an efficient approach to combine the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. It has been used in several systems, such as the cycloaddition of epoxides [14,15], and Suzuki coupling reactions [16-18]. For hydroformylation, similar methods have been put forward, such as supported ionic liquid phase (SILP) catalysts and covalently coupling active species [19-21]. In previous work, the covalently coupled catalyst showed high stability but its activity needs further improvement [21]. The factors that affect activity was also studied rarely. If the ligands were directly supported on supports, Wilkinson-type catalysts were formed, which were thought as active species [22]. However, supported catalyst had higher electronic density to enhance the adsorption and activation of reactant, and ligands provided larger steric interspace on catalyst surface benefited the reaction [23]. Dppe and dppp are widely used phosphine ligands for homogeneous catalysts [24-27]. They belong to a series of commercially available dpp* ligands ( Scheme 1 ). For hydroformylation reactions, these ligands have been used in homogeneous systems for some reactants [28-30], but their use in heterogeneous catalysts have not been studied. Herein, a series of dpp* phosphines were studied to clarify the effect of ligand on supported Rh/SiO2 catalysts in ethene hydroformylation. The catalysts were characterized by TEM, TGA, and N2 adsorption-desorption. The influence of CO and formation of active species were studied by CO-TPD and in situ FTIR. Catalytic performance was studied in ethene hydroformylation, and the mechanism of hydroformylation activity enhancement by ligands was proposed. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The Rh/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). SiO2 was purchased from Alfa Aesar (China) and crushed to 80-120 mesh. Rh(NO3)3 precursor (5% in HNO3(aq)) was purchased from Innochem (China). Rh(NO3)3 solution was diluted with a specific amount of deionized water and then added to SiO2 dropwise. After being stirred uniformly, the sample was ultrasonically treated for 2 h and calcined at 450 °C for 3 h. The loading of phosphine ligands was also realized by IWI. All the ligands used are commercially available ( Scheme 1 ). Typically, a designed amount of ligand was first dissolved in a suitable volume of toluene and then impregnated onto the Rh/SiO2 catalyst. The catalyst was dried at room temperature, and was named as Rh-xLn/SiO2, where x was the molar ratio between ligand and Rh, and n was length of carbon chain of the ligand. PPh3 was also studied over Rh/SiO2 with a P/Rh ratio of 10, and the catalyst was denoted as Rh-10PPh3/SiO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology of the catalysts was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images on a JEM2010 TEM with an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. Before the TEM imaging, the catalysts were first activated in reaction atmosphere at 140 °C for 30 min and then dispersed in alcohol. The amount of supported phosphine ligands and their thermal stability were tested by themogravitimetric analysis (TGA) using a Mettler-Toledo TGA/DSC1/1600LF analyzer under N2 atmosphere. The specific surface area of catalysts was determined by N2 adsorption at 77 K using a Quantachrome autosorb iQ and AsiQwin instrument. The results were calculated with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) methods. The active species of the catalysts were investigated by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy using Thermo Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT-A) detector. Typically, ~15 mg catalyst was pressed onto a tungsten mesh and then placed in the center of the measurement cell. To exclude the influence of CO adsorption amount, all the catalysts were exposed to adsorbates longer than 30 min to reach stable. The CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) was conducted on a laboratory-made fixed-bed reactor equipped with an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50). For each measurement, ~25 mg catalyst was first pretreated in 10% CO/10% H2/80% N2 at 140 °C for 30 min. After cooling to 40 оC under N2 atmosphere, 10% CO/90% N2 was introduced to saturate the sample for 30 min. Then the sample was purged in pure N2 for 30 min, followed by temperature ramping to 450 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min. An ice-water condenser was added between the reactor and detector. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The influence of phosphine ligands on Rh/SiO2 was evaluated by gaseous hydroformylation of C2H4. Pure CO and C2H4 were purchased from Air Liquid (China), and the other gases were provided by Beiwen (China). For each test, 0.1 g of catalyst was loaded in the reaction tube of a fixed bed reactor. After reaching the specific temperature under N2, reactant gases (C2H4:H2:CO:N2 = 1:1:1:1) were switched into the reaction tube and the system was pressurized to 1 MPa. The outlet stream was analyzed online using a gas chromatograph (GC). The oxygenates such as propanal, propanol and 2-methyl-2-pentenal (2M2P) were separated using a capillary column (Agilent, HP-INNOWax) and detected with a flame ionization detector (FID), while the other products were separated by packed columns (Agilent, Molsieve 5A and HayeSep N 80) and detected with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). N2 was used as internal standard substance and the carbon balance of each catalyst was between 0.95 and 1.02, indicating that the products that were not detected by GC could be neglected. The catalytic activity, conversion, selectivity and product yield were calculated by the following equations: Activity ( mol · molRh − 1 · h − 1 ) = ∑ n i F i m Rh / M Rh Conversion ( % ) = ∑ n i F i F C 2 H 4 , out + ∑ n i F i × 100 % Selectivity i ( % ) = n i F i ∑ n i F i × 100 % Yield i ( % ) = n i F i F C 2 H 4 , out + ∑ n i F i × 100 % where ni = 1 for i = ethane, propanal, and n-propanol, ni = 2 for i = 2M2P, Fi is the molar flow rate of product i, m Rh is the total mass of Rh used for reaction, and M Rh is the relative atomic mass of Rh. The CO cutoff transient experiment was carried out on the same equipment as hydroformylation evaluation. For each test, 0.1 g catalyst was used. After being heated to the set temperature, the hydroformylation experiment (C2H4:H2:CO:N2 = 1:1:1:1) was first conducted at 1 MPa to activate the catalyst, then CO was cut off (C2H4:H2:N2 = 1:1:2) to carry out the hydrogenation reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The loading of phosphine ligand on each catalyst was measured by TGA. As listed in Table 1 , the Rh/SiO2 catalyst had only 1.3% weight loss, while the phosphine-modified catalysts had much higher weight loss of ~15%. The TG and DTG curves are shown in Fig. 1 and Figure S1, respectively. All catalysts exhibited obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 200-400 °C. Rh-5L2/SiO2 and Rh-5L6/SiO2 also had slight weight loss below 200 °C. The peaks below 200 °C originated from adsorbed H2O and toluene, and those above 200 °C were attributed to desorption and decomposition of phosphines. The actual P/Rh mole ratios were calculated from the TG data. The results showed that the P/Rh atomic ratios were ~10. The specific surface areas of the catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . All the catalysts exhibited typical type IV isotherms (Figure S2). The Rh/SiO2 catalyst had a BET area of 144 m2/g. The introduction of phosphine ligand decreased it to 128 m2/g for Rh-5L1/SiO2 and 88 m2/g for Rh-5L3/SiO2. Rh-5L5/SiO2 and Rh-5L6/SiO2 had similar BET area to that of Rh-5L3/SiO2. The TEM images (Figure S2) of the Rh/SiO2 and Rh-xLn/SiO2 catalysts show a size distribution of Rh NPs between 1 and 8 nm with similar mean size of ~2 nm. The introduction of phosphine did not obviously change the size of Rh NPs. The dispersion of Rh NPs was also calculated based on particle size. As shown in Table 1 , the particle dispersions of all the catalysts were in the range of 22-26%. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation The role of ligands in heterogeneous ethene hydroformylation was investigated with dpp* series molecules ( Fig. 2 and Table S1). Considering that the supported homogeneous catalysts usually have an activation period, all data were collected at the time on stream (TOS) of 3 h. For Rh/SiO2 without the modification of ligand, the reaction rate at 140 °C was only 10.3 molC2H4/(molRh⋅h) with 65% oxygenate selectivity, which was consistent with previous work [31]. The oxygenate products contained propanal, 2M2P, and propanol, where propanal was the main oxygenate product. Compared with Rh/SiO2, the selectivity to oxygenates was enhanced to 94% over Rh-5L1/SiO2 and even enhanced to ~97% over the other phosphine modified catalysts. For Rh-5L3/SiO2, Rh-5L5/SiO2, Rh-5L6/SiO2 and Rh-10PPh3/SiO2, the selectivity to propanal was significantly increased to ~95% compared to 57% over Rh/SiO2, and the selectivity to 2M2P was decreased to ~1% compared to 8% over Rh/SiO2. The other two phosphine-modified catalysts, Rh-5L1/SiO2 and Rh-5L2/SiO2, showed higher selectivity to 2M2P, especially Rh-5L2/SiO2. The 2M2P selectivity on Rh-5L2/SiO2 was 16%, indicating that this ligand promoted the dimerization of propanal. The selectivity to propanol on all the modified catalysts were less than 2%. As 2M2P and propanol were both formed through hydroformylation, the selectivity to total oxygenates was considered to compare the hydroformylation ability in Fig. 2 . All the catalysts modified with phosphine ligands also showed higher activity than Rh/SiO2, but the structure of ligands exhibited different effects on the catalytic performance. The enhanced activity over ligand modified catalysts decreased in the following trends: Rh-5L5/SiO2 > Rh-5L6/SiO2 ~ Rh-10PPh3/SiO2 > Rh-5L3/SiO2 > Rh-5L2/SiO2 > Rh-5L1/SiO2, where Rh-5L1/SiO2 had a similar reaction rate of 13.3 molC2H4/(molRh⋅h) to that of Rh/SiO2 and Rh-5L5/SiO2 catalyst had the highest activity of 1172 molC2H4/(molRh⋅h) which was 100 times higher than that of Rh/SiO2. Catalyst stability of Rh-5L5/SiO2 was also investigated by long-time-evaluation. As shown in Figure S3, within 20 h, the activity and selectivity remained at ~1000 molC2H4/(molRh⋅h) and 98%, respectively. However, to make the catalyst more stable in a longer evaluation period or liquid phase reaction, an improvement of catalyst to tether the ligands on the support was necessary [21]. The influence of ligand-to-Rh (L5/Rh) ratio was evaluated using L5 as an example. As shown in Figure S4, the activity first increased with the L5/Rh ratio, but started to decrease at the ratio of 15, indicating that an excess amount of ligand has negative effects on the activity. Similar results were reported in previous works that the optimal ratio of tris(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenyl)phosphite to Rh was 40 for ethene hydroformylation and the optimal ratio of PPh3 to Rh was 15 for propylene hydroformylation [8,22]. It was reported that phosphine and carbon monoxide adsorbed competitively over the Rh sites, but much excess ligands could lead to 18 e− saturated state of Rh and passivate the Rh active sites [22]. Thus, an optimized ratio of ligand/Rh was required for the hydroformylation reaction. It should be noted that the L5/Rh ratio did not affect the selectivity to oxygenates obviously, which could be ascribed to the much lower activity of the unmodified or saturated Rh than phosphine coordinated catalyst. The influence of reaction temperature was studied with Rh-5L5/SiO2. The results are shown in Figure S5. Compared to Rh/SiO2, the Rh-5L5/SiO2 was much more active for ethene hydroformylation, giving a reaction rate of ~180 molC2H4/(molRh⋅h) even at 80 °C. However, a long period of ~20 h was required to activate the catalyst, and the activity was only ~15% of that at 140 °C. When the reaction temperature increased to 100 °C and 140 °C, the activation period was greatly reduced to ~5 h and ~1 h, respectively. According to several researches, there was an activation period of hydroformylation [22,32]. The active species of catalyst was formed gradually. A suitable amount of dimerization formed during this period also enhanced the activity [32]. Higher temperature may accelerate the formation of these species, so the observed activation period was shortened. The catalyst activity increased with the increasing temperature from 80 °C to 100 °C. However, further increasing the temperature to 140 °C slightly decreased the activity, which was likely attributed to weaker adsorption of CO at high temperatures (See Section 3.4.2). 3.3 Active species on catalysts surfaces Phosphine ligands enhance the hydroformylation performance of both homogeneous and heterogeneous Rh catalysts. Compared to other modification, catalysts modified by phosphines exhibited much higher activity and selectivity (Table S2). It has been reported that hydride-Rh carbonyl species was formed on phosphine modified catalysts [22,23], but previous reports were based on pre-reduced catalysts, which were different from the present catalysts. In order to reveal the underlying generation of active species during hydroformylation reaction, in situ FTIR experiments was used to evaluate the present catalysts. We first investigated the influence of pretreatment condition on Rh-5L5/SiO2. As shown in Fig. 3 , only a weak response occurred at the region of 1985-1942 cm−1 with introducing CO, while intense absorption signal appeared at 2048-1883 cm−1 with further introducing H2. The absorbance at 2048-1883 cm−1 was enhanced gradually during the detection period at 140 °C (Figure S6), indicating that the formation of active species experienced a period of time. With pretreating the catalyst under reaction atmosphere (CO/H2/C2H4/He), the IR spectrum showed similar absorption peaks as those in CO/H2/He (Figure S7). These results indicated that the unreduced Rh NP adsorbed rare CO under merely CO atmosphere, but active Rh species was formed efficiently with the co-existence of H2 and CO. As shown in Fugure S7, there were four bands appearing after pretreating Rh-5L5/SiO2 with CO/H2/He. The weak band at 2085 cm−1 was attributed to the unmodified gem-dicarbonyl rhodium species, Rh(CO)2 [33]. The bands at 2002 and 1965 cm−1 were attributed to the adsorbed CO on phosphine-modified Rh species (HRh(CO) x L5 y, x + y ≤ 4, 2040-1940 cm−1) [12,22]. The CO vibration frequency was lower for the HRh(CO) x L5 y species than that of Rh(CO)2, because the addition of ligand L5 enhanced the electron back donation from Rh center to CO. Therefore, the electrons between C and O were reduced and the C=O bond was weakened. The broad band at ~1800 cm−1 was attributed to bridge-adsorbed CO [22]. Some researches suggested that for phosphine-modified heterogeneous catalysts, the active species still acted homogeneously at reaction conditions [19,22], but the spectra of adsorbed CO of ligand-modified heterogeneous catalysts were different from those of supported homogeneous catalysts, which suggested the different interactions of active sites and support between these two catalysts [22,23]. It was difficult to determine the precise configuration of quasi-homogeneous species in Rh-5L5/SiO2. However, compared to Rh/SiO2, different active species were formed upon exposure to syngas over the phosphine modified catalyst. After 15 min adsorption, the wavenumber of active species kept unchanged (Figure S6), indicating that more than one CO were adsorbed on each Rh site because it was reported that the wavenumber of linear adsorbed CO on Rh was affected by the adsorption amount, while the wavenumber of Rh(CO)2 was independent of the adsorption amount [22,33]. These active species over Rh-5L5/SiO2 were closely correlated with the enhanced catalytic performance discussed below. Similar to Rh-5L5/SiO2, all the other phosphine-modified catalysts had an obvious band at ~2000 cm−1 (Figure S8), indicating the formation of HRh(CO) x (L) y active species. However, the wavenumber of active species over phosphine modified catalysts showed different degrees of red-shift compared to that over Rh/SiO2, following the trend: Rh-10PPh3/SiO2 < Rh-5L5/SiO2 < Rh-5L6/SiO2 < Rh-5L3/SiO2 < Rh-5L2/SiO2 < Rh-5L1/SiO2. The electron interaction between ligands and Rh increased the electron density on Rh center and thus leaded to the red-shift of HRh(CO) x L y [24]. In homogeneous catalysts, the electron deficiency of Rh was beneficial for hydroformylation activity [1,8]. However, the phosphine ligand generally increased the electron density of center metal [22,34]. In order to determine the electronic effect of phosphine ligands, the reaction activity of the phosphine-modified catalysts were correlated with the wavenumber of active species. As shown in Fig. 4 , volcanic profile was occurred that Rh-5L5/SiO2 with middle wavenumber of active species gave the best activity. Other catalysts departure this wavenumber showed correlated decreasing activity and L1 was the least active modifier as the wavenumber of HRh(CO) x L1 y active species was only 1989 cm−1, far away from HRh(CO) x L5 y . The wavenumber of active species was related to the electronic state of phosphine-modified Rh. the volcanic profile suggests that an optimized electronic state benefits the hydroformylation activity. 3.4 Rate-limiting step on different catalysts The hydroformylation reaction contains two H addition steps and one CO insertion step ( Scheme 2 ) [3,35], any of which was possible to be the rate-limiting step (RLS). As discussed above, the active species changed with the type of catalysts, and thus it is necessary to check the RLS of these catalysts. Different results on the RLS in hydroformylation reaction have been reported in literatures [8,31,36-40], and the RLS was influenced by the active sites. In homogeneous systems, most experimental and theoretical studies acknowledged that H addition, including either alkene insertion or oxidative addition of hydrogen, was the RLS [8,37-39]. In some heterogeneous systems, CO insertion was the most energetically demanding step, for example, on ReOx modified Rh [31] and Rh(111), RhCo(111) surfaces [36]. However, doping inorganic phosphorus to Rh changed the active sites to Rh2P and the H addition became rate-determining [40]. The supported Rh/SiO2 catalyst with phosphine modification was between homogeneous and heterogeneous systems and the kinetic mode might followed homogeneous counterparts [22], the applicability of which in dpp* ligands required more verifications. 3.4.1 CO transient experiment The measurement of kinetics and determine the RLS of certain catalysts traditionally required tedious kinetic studies [37,41,42]. The hydrogenation reaction in the absence of CO represented the ability of H addition in hydroformylation. Herein, CO cutoff transient experiments are performed to distinguish the RLS and understand the role of different active species. CO was first introduced to the reaction system (CO:H2:C2H4:N2 = 1:1:1:1) to conduct the hydroformylation reaction and activate the catalyst. Simultaneously, the hydrogenation was observed as the side reaction. After 1 h reaction, the CO was cut off (C2H4:H2:N2 =1:1:2) and the change of reaction rate was detected. To make the discussion brief, the total yield of oxygenates was considered to represent hydroformylation ability. Fig. 5 shows that under hydroformylation conditions, the Rh/SiO2 catalyst had low yields of both oxygenate and ethane. The ethane yield increased significantly from 0.5% to 81% when CO was cut off, and it dropped back to 0.7% after reintroduction of CO. During the CO transient experiment, the oxygenate yield kept below 2% during two steady-state periods. With the Rh-5L5/SiO2 catalyst, the oxygenate yield was 36% under hydroformylation conditions, while the cut-off of CO increased the ethane yield to ~25% and decreased the oxygenate yield significantly to nearly 0. The different evolution of reaction rates indicated the different RLS over Rh/SiO2 and Rh-5L5/SiO2. Over Rh/SiO2, in the presence of CO, both hydrogenation and hydroformylation rates were low, as if the active sites were ‘poisoned’ by CO. When CO was cut off, the limitation by CO disappeared and the ability of H addition was recovered, leading to a much higher ethene conversion. This result indicated that the rate of H addition was significantly quicker than CO insertion and the hydroformylation reaction rate on Rh/SiO2 was limited by CO insertion step, which was consistent with our previous research [36]. On the contrary, no matter CO existed or not, the ethene conversion kept at a high level over Rh-5L5/SiO2. It can be inferred that the RLS of hydroformylation on Rh-5L5/SiO2 was H addition. The existence of CO just determined whether the ethene was converted to aldehydes or ethane, without changing the overall conversion. Therefore, the higher hydroformylation activity and selectivity of Rh-5L5/SiO2 was attributed to the different RLS from Rh/SiO2. The yield of oxygenate had a short-term unsteady state just after CO cutoff. On Rh/SiO2, it first increased, then decreased to approximate zero, while on Rh-5L5/SiO2, it decreased directly. After CO cutoff, the concentration of adsorbed CO decreased, but some CO remained. This change of surface CO would change the reaction rate of hydroformylation. We speculated that the activity will increase with diluted CO if CO insertion is the RLS, and the activity will decrease with reduced CO if the oxidative addition of hydrogen is the RLS [22,31]. The contrary response of oxygenate yields on Rh/SiO2 and Rh-5L5/SiO2 can be attributed to their different RLSs. The relationship between hydroformylation and hydrogenation was also studied over other phosphine-modified catalysts ( Fig. 6 ). All the catalysts showed slightly lower ethane yield under hydrogenation condition (C2H4:H2:N2 =1:1:2) than oxygenate yield under hydroformylation condition (C2H4:H2:CO:N2 =1:1:1:1), indicating that the hydroformylation rate was not limited by CO insertion step. The hydroformylation activity of the Rh-L/SiO2 catalysts showed a positive correlation with their hydrogenation activity, implying that the hydroformylation rate was mainly affected by the rate of H addition. However, Rh/SiO2 was an outlier, which had the highest activity of hydrogenation but the lowest activity of hydroformylation. The explanation is that the RLS on Rh/SiO2 was CO insertion instead of H addition, causing that the hydroformylation rate was restricted by CO insertion step and showed no relation to hydrogenation rate. These comparing results confirmed that the reaction on Rh-L/SiO2 and Rh/SiO2 obeyed different mechanisms. 3.4.2 CO-TPD CO-TPD was used to study the change of interaction between CO and catalysts and further prove the change on RLS for different catalysts. It should be mentioned that phosphine ligands may desorb or decompose from catalyst surface at these temperatures, which may interfere the CO-TPD results. As expressed in Section 2.2, this influence had been eliminated by adding a cold trap downstream the samples. Figure S9 showed that the catalyst pretreated under N2 contributed rarely to the signal, thus the ligands desorption or decomposition would not influence the analysis. Fig. 7 shows the CO-TPD profiles of Rh based catalysts. It should be noted that CO2 was formed in the CO-TPD process, as shown in Fig. 7 b. According to Deutschmann and Karakaya [43], CO2 was generated in three possible ways: CO oxidation via chemisorbed oxygen, CO dissociation, and water gas shift reaction. Considering the different temperature ranges of these reactions [44-46], at low temperature, the formation of CO2 was likely due to the oxidation of CO by chemisorbed oxygen, and at high temperature, CO2 was attributed to CO dissociation and water gas shift reaction. On Rh/SiO2, rare CO was detected but CO2 signal was apparent. The desorption profiles of CO and CO2 on Rh-L/SiO2 showed distinct differences from that on Rh/SiO2. All the phosphine-modified catalysts showed one CO desorption peak at temperatures between 100 and 300 °C, with onset desorption temperature below 200 °C. These catalysts also showed broad peaks of CO2 signal, but the signal was much weaker compared with Rh/SiO2, as shown in Fig. 7 b. The obvious desorption of CO2 on Rh/SiO2 indicated that the CO interacted with Rh strongly and part of them were only active at high temperatures. After the introduction of phosphines, Rh had more appropriate interaction strength with CO, thus the desorption temperatures were weaker and the dissociation of CO was partly inhibited. The weak adsorption made the CO insertion step easy in hydroformylation, while the sites leading to CO2 may cause hydrogenation or be inert at the reaction temperature [47]. The FTIR results showed that the active species was Rh(CO)2 and HRh(CO) x L y on Rh/SiO2 and Rh-L/SiO2, respectively, the latter of which had higher activity and selectivity. The CO transient analysis indicated that the promotion of phosphine was attributed to the decrease of activation barrier and change of RLS, which could be explained by CO-TPD results that these HRh(CO) x L y species modulated the CO desorption mode and suppressed the decomposition of CO. For Rh/SiO2, CO interacted with Rh strongly, thus the movement and insertion of CO was difficult, leading to a high energy barrier. With introduction of phosphine, the interaction between CO and Rh sites became weaker and the energy barrier of CO insertion step decreased so that the RLS changed to H insertion steps. Because of these changes of CO adsorption, all phosphine modified Rh/SiO2 showed enhanced hydroformylation activity and selectivity, as shown in Fig. 2 . Among the different ligands-modified catalysts, the different electronic states of Rh in HRh(CO) x L y changed the H addition ability of catalysts and led to the different hydroformylation activities. 4 Conclusions A set of commercially available dpp* phosphine ligands were used to modify the Rh/SiO2 catalyst in heterogeneous gaseous hydroformylation. In situ FTIR spectroscopy showed that the pseudo-homogeneous species, HRh(CO) x L y , were formed on the Rh-L/SiO2 catalysts, which showed very different behavior from Rh/SiO2. The formed active species altered the RLS of hydroformylation reaction, from CO insertion to H addition. The ethene hydroformylation activity was enhanced by ~100 times over the Rh-5L5/SiO2 catalyst compared with Rh/SiO2. With the assistance of phosphine ligand, the hydroformylation was more likely to occur and thus the selectivity to oxygenates increased from 65% to ~97%. Among the dpp* phosphine ligands studied, L5 and L6 showed significant promotion, while the activity of L1 and L2 catalysts were only slightly enhanced. The low activity improvement of L1 and L2 was attributed to their intense electronic donation. coredata.dc:description: Hydroformylation is applied in industry to convert olefin and syngas to value-added products. Rh promoted by phosphine ligands are highly efficient catalysts for this reaction. The promotion mechanism of phosphines has been well studied in homogeneous system. It is important to extend the use of these ligands to heterogeneous system. The dpp* (PPh2(CH2) n PPh2, n = 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6) ligands were introduced to Rh/SiO2 and the ethene gaseous hydroformylation reaction was tested. Compared to unmodified Rh/SiO2, all the catalysts modified by phosphine showed enhanced activity (~100 times higher for the best ligand) and oxygenate selectivity (from 65% to ~97%). Among the investigation, L5 and L6 ligands exhibited the best performance while L1 and L2 only gave slight promotion. CO cutoff transient experiments were designed to identify the rate-limiting step (RLS) of hydroformylation reaction over the present catalysts. A mechanism was proposed for the change of RLS over the phosphine modified catalysts. Combined with in situ FTIR results, the relationship between electronic state and catalytic activity of the catalyst was verified.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion of diphosphine ligands (PPh2(CH2) n PPh2, n = 1, 2, 3, 5, 6) for supported Rh/SiO2 catalysts in heterogeneous ethene hydroformylation
